intro: Dipcadi madrasicum, commonly known as the Persian lily, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the Middle East and parts of Central Asia. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its tall, erect stems and showy, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid climates. Its bulbs are often used in traditional medicine for their purported healing properties. The species is also valued for its ornamental appeal in gardens and floral arrangements.
